Sorry, that last message was sent prematurely.  I'm still pretty  
clumsy o=
n the iPhone.

I found separate speciation code in the reproduction logic t=
hat  
appears to be correct.  My only concern, then, is the growth of the  =

number of species mentioned in the original email.

I'm also curious about=
 the "dropoff age" feature that kills off  
species that have been around f=
or a certain number of generations  
(default is 50).  Is this a standard N=
EAT feature?

Daniel

On Mar 7, 2010, at 2:43 PM, Daniel Tuohy <danielr2e@g=
mail.com> wrote:

ere is

>=

iptions in NEAT papers and discussion in this forum.  There is

ng into the details of the JNeat code.

on as occuring every generation.   
>> Speciation entails iterating over th=
e population, and performing

tibility function and

d, this algorithm is implemented in JNeat as the speciate()  
>> method, bu=
t its only invoked at the beginning of evolution and

 growth and death of species afterwards is

the epoch() method that does not appear

I'm concerned that whatever JNeat is

ind, and it leads to some strange

ng how the number of species

  With a population size

400 before leveling

iate() method be called after ever generation/

oo many species?  Approximately how many

the XOR experiment with 500 individuals?

      <p>Hello,</p><d=
iv><br></div><div>My refactoring of JNeat has brought me to the speciation =
code, and I'm finding it tricky to reconcile the JNeat speciation code with=
 descriptions in NEAT papers and discussion in this forum.  There is a=
 lot going on here, but I think I can state the problem simply without gett=
ing into the details of the JNeat code.  </div>

<div><br></div><div>K=
en's paper describes speciation as occuring every generation.  Speciat=
ion entails iterating over the population, and performing some rudimentary =
clustering using a compatibility function and threshhold.  Pretty stra=
ightforward.</div>

<div><br></div><div>Indeed, this algorithm is implement=
ed in JNeat as the speciate() method, but its only invoked at the beginning=
 of evolution and never again!  The growth and death of species afterw=
ards is determined by some code in the epoch() method that does not appear =
to resemble NEAT speciation.  I'm concerned that whatever JNeat is doi=
ng, it isn't what Ken had in mind, and it leads to some strange behavior. &=
nbsp;Attached is a graph showing how the number of species grows during a r=
un of the XOR experiment.  With a population size of 500, it increases=
 almost monotonically to 400 before leveling off after 40 generations. &nbs=
p;</div>

<div><br></div><div>Shouldn't the speciate() method be called aft=
er ever generation/epoch?  Isn't this way too many species?  Appr=
oximately how many species would you expect for the XOR experiment with 500=
 individuals?</div>

<div><br></div><div><br></div><div>Regards,</div><div>=
Daniel</div>
